about.name: Dr. Gargi Sarkar
about.affiliation: International Institute of Information Technology (IIIT) Hyderabad

points: As a researcher at the intersection of computer security and criminology, I investigate cybercrimes targeting everyday individuals. My work aims to develop efficient and systematic policing procedures to combat these crimes. I have been actively involved in mitigating and synthesizing solutions for cyber-enabled human trafficking and forced criminality affecting victims of trafficking. Currently, I am developing standard operating procedures for police to systematically investigate digital artifacts involved in cybercrimes, incorporating open-source intelligence, and fostering private-government collaboration.

research.title: Doctoral Research (Ph.D.) | Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur
details: Thesis: Digital Investigative Infrastructures for Cybercrime: A Human-Centric Approach from India’s Policing Perspective
Supervisor: Prof. Sandeep Kumar Shukla
Research integrates investigative tooling, human-centric cybercrime analysis, organized cybercriminal networks, cyber slavery, and international cybercrime law from an Indian policing perspective.

research.title: Building Framework for Cybercrime Investigations | Funded by Microsoft Research India
details: Led the development of Cybercrime Navigator.
Developed a TTP-based framework dividing the cybercrime lifecycle into 14 stages.
Defined techniques, sub-techniques, and digital artifacts for each stage.
Designed and implemented an interactive investigative tool with automated modus operandi identification.

research.title: Studied Indian Organized Cybercriminal Networks
details: Analyzed organizational structures, social engineering techniques, division of labor, and tiered operational hierarchies.
Highlighted transformation into family-run enterprises and cybercrime-as-a-service models.

research.title: Cybercrime and Human Trafficking
details: Explored bidirectional relationship between cybercrime and human trafficking.
Developed a five-tier victimization model illustrating trafficking, confinement, and forced participation.

research.title: Legal and Policy Analysis of Cybercrime
details: Constructed actor-intent and target-impact models to differentiate cybercrime, cyberattacks, and cyberterrorism.
Evaluated the Budapest Convention and the proposed UN Convention against Cybercrime.

research.title: Dark Web Analysis and Monitoring | M.Sc. Thesis
details: Conducted theoretical analysis of Dark Web crawling using Tor.
Developed onion URL connectivity graphs.
Assessed feasibility of tracing users.

projects.title: Cyber Commando Operational Manual

Contributed sections on digital forensics, electronic evidence handling, and legal compliance.

projects.title: Comparison of Network-based Intrusion Detection Systems
